abstract:
The RBT (River Buffers and Terraces) toolkit is a set of GIS tools designed to analyze river channels within the ESRI ArcGIS Desktop software. This method uses high-resolution Digital Elevation Models (DEMs) derived from sources such as LiDAR or ground surveys, allowing for detailed description and measurement of river features.

The toolkit calculates various profile metrics at regular intervals along the length of a site, with the interval distance being customizable. These metrics include mean, standard deviation, coefficient of variation, filtered means and standard deviations, and all profile values with their cumulative interval distances. The filtered metrics exclude outliers by removing any values more than a set number of standard deviations from the population mean â€“ in this case, four standard deviations for CHaMP 2011 data.

The RBT method is essential as it provides detailed and accurate analysis of river channels, enabling users to identify trends, anomalies, and changes over time. It is particularly useful when dealing with large datasets or complex rivers where a high level of precision is required for effective monitoring and management. This method solves the challenges of manual data processing and interpretation by automating the process, increasing efficiency and reducing potential errors.

description:
The River Bed Technology (RBT) is a collection of Geographic Information System (GIS) tools integrated within ESRI ArcGIS Desktop software. This toolkit enables users to characterize and quantify river channels employing high-resolution Digital Elevation Models (DEMs). Obtained from sources like airborne remote sensing, such as Light Detection and Ranging (LiDAR), or ground-based topographic surveys, DEMs serve as the fundamental input for subsequent analysis.

The RBT computes various profile metrics at consistent intervals along the length of a specified site. The interval distance is adjustable based on user preferences. For instance, in the 2011 CHaMP project, the interval distance was set to 0.5 meters. Each profile metric consists of several outputs:

1. Mean value for all profile metrics
2. Standard deviation across all profile values
3. Coefficient of variation (CV) across all profile values
4. Filtered mean of select profile intervals
5. Filtered standard deviation across chosen profile intervals
6. Filtered CV across all selected profile values
7. All profile values alongside their respective cumulative interval distances downstream from the site's top.

Filtered metrics only report statistics for a predefined subset of profile intervals, effectively eliminating any values that deviate more than a specified number of standard deviations from the overall mean population. For 2011 CHaMP data, this filtering threshold was set at four standard deviations to exclude outliers from the metrics.

The CHaMP - Topographic Point Collection Methods documentation provides context regarding the collection of measurement data that undergo this calculation process. (http://www.monitoringmethods.org/Method/Details/836)
